comments.content: Tested - this is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
For me the Answers are :
1-Case is resolved, open activities are caneled/
 when resolving a case with open activities, and before the case resolution form, a prompted message shows to ask confirmation to cancel associated open activities
2-Case is resolved, Entitlement is decremented by six hours/ which is logic because the billable time is six hours, and we can't charge the customer the total time for each case it doesnt make a sense
3-Open activities of child cases remain open/which is the default behaviour on parent child case settings in service management

i believe the first answer might be correct because the owner of case might not have privileges to close the activities of other users so the case it can't be resolved, as other activities need to be closed first.

Guys, I have tested the system and the answers should be:
1. Case is resolved, open activities are cancelled.
2. Case is resolved, entitlement is decremented by 6 hours following the billable time.
3. By default, when a parent case is resolved, its child cases are still open and thus, their activities are still open.
But if you select resolving child cases when parent case is resolved, then open activities are CLOSED, not CANCELLED as you thought.

The answer are incorrect.
Correct answer:
1. Case is resolved. Open activities are canceled.
2. Case is resolved. Entitlement is decremented by six hours.
3. Opens activities of child cases are canceled.
If you are resolving a case you have to enter a Resolution, even you text "Case is not resolved. Open activities must be closed" the default behavior of the system is to cancel all open activities of the resolved case.

Clair you said: "and in any case they wouldn't be canceled but completed", but this page https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/customer-service-hub-user-guide-case-sla#resolve-a-case says:

questions.question_text:
A company uses Dynamics 365 Customer Service.
You are configuring the advanced similarity rules. You create a similarity rule on cases and put an exact match for the Modified On field in the Match Fields tab.
You test the rule and discover that exact matches do not appear.
You need to determine why the rule is not working.
What are two possible reasons why the rule is not working? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
No Similarity rules are not Duplicate detection rules! They are used to search for similar cases.
https://docs.microsoft.com
To my mind the answers are B and C. The C because you have to have enabled privilege.
E is wrong because in the documentation it is said:
For a field to be eligible for exact matching, it must meet the following criteria:
• It can't be a Primary Key.
• It can't be these types: String, Memo, Picklist, Boolean, Whole Number, Two Options, Date and Time, or Floating Point Number.
• It can be these types: Lookup, OptionSet, Customer, Owner, Status, State, Status Reason.
In the solution Modified On is Date and Time, so it cannot be enabled for Similarity rules.
/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/suggest-similar-cases-for-a-case

1. Similarity Rule is now Duplication Rule. And a duplication rule cannot be activated/deactivated but published/unpublished, so D is the first correct answer.
2. If the modified-on field is not set to searchable, duplication rule cannot search for modified-on field on any records, the next correct answer is E.
